Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Design of Ionic-Liquid-Biocatalyst Systems for Production of Platform Chemicals and Intermediates Directly from Plant Biomass

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the future, for biorefineries to operate economically, they will require an integrated process with the complete use of all carbons in the lignocellulosic biomass including cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin to produce biofuels, biochemicals, and biomaterials. Biomass is difficult to process, however. Ionic liquid (IL) pretreatment is an emerging technology that aids biomass processing. For its successful commercialization, this technology must overcome significant barriers, namely cost of the ILs, recycling expense, and general toxicity to biocatalysts. To tackle these barriers, the objective of the proposed research is to develop novel highly-compatible IL-biocatalyst systems for simultaneous saccharification and fermentation (SSF-IL) of lignocellulosic biomass into high-value organic chemicals (HVOs).

Specifically, the team will fundamentally study and optimize high IL-tolerance of Yarrowia lipolytica, a generally regarded-as-safe oleaginous yeast, that can thrive and perform efficient biotransformation in at least a 10% IL solution. The team will also elucidate and optimize Y. lipolytica metabolism for efficient co-utilization of glucose and xylose, the major sugars of lignocellulosic biomass. Finally, the team will develop highly compatible IL-biocatalyst systems for enhanced conversion of lignocellulosic hybrid poplar (a potential bioenergy crop), into high-value organics, specifically alpha-ketoglutaric acid via SSF-IL.

The project will gain fundamental understanding of how the engineered IL-biocatalyst system can transform recalcitrant biomass into valuable biofuels, biochemicals, and biomaterials, and demonstrate a model for an unconventional, economical, and competitive integrated biorefinery. It will present a promising sustainable pathway for energy independence, security, and a greener environment by utilizing renewable, sustainable, and domestic lignocellulosic biomass instead of fossil fuels. The project will also provide educational components including training of postdoctoral, graduate and (underrepresented minority) undergraduate students in the areas of biomass conversion, biocatalysis, systems biology, and metabolic engineering. In addition, outreach will involve engaging undergraduate students in the Internationally Genetically Engineered Machinery (iGEM) program that the PI has organized since 2012 as well as organizing summer workshops for K-12 students who will be exposed to various aspects of Catalysis and Biocatalysis to address challenging energy-related problems. The project is co-funded by the NSF Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the future, for biorefineries to operate economically, they will require an integrated process with the complete use of all carbons in the lignocellulosic biomass including cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin to produce biofuels, biochemicals, and biomaterials. For instance, cellulose and hemicellulose could be used to produce high-value biochemicals and biofuels, while lignin, which constitutes up to 30% of the biomass, could be harnessed as a valuable biomaterial (e.g., carbon fibers) instead of being underused as a heating source in current biorefinery processes. The challenge is to overcome biomass recalcitrance to effectively process these components as available feedstocks for efficient downstream processing. Ionic liquid (IL) pretreatment is an emerging technology to effectively reduce the biomass recalcitrance. However, for its successful commercialization, this technology must overcome some significant barriers related to ionic liquids: ILs are costly, expensive to recycle, and generally toxic to biocatalysts. To tackle these barriers, this project aimed to develop novel highly-compatible IL-biocatalyst systems for simultaneous saccharification and fermentation (SSF-IL) of lignocellulosic biomass into high-value organics (HVOs). The team has successfully completed the following research aims: i) Designed, characterized, and elucidated novel IL systems for effective biomass activation and fractionation to harness C5 and C6 sugars and lignins for downstream processing; ii) Significantly enhanced and shed lights on the underlying mechanisms of exceptional IL-tolerance of the GRAS oleaginous yeast, Yarrowia lipolytica that can thrive and perform efficient biotransformation in various ILs at high concentrations up to 18% (v/v); iii) Elucidated and optimized Y. lipolytica metabolism for efficient co-utilization of glucose, xylose, and arabinose as the major sugars of lignocellulosic biomass and developed highly compatible IL-biocatalyst systems for enhanced conversion of lignocellulosic biomass, hybrid poplar as a bioenergy crop, into high value organics, alpha-ketoglutaric acid in SSF-IL.

Completion of this project has generated a better understanding of how the engineered IL-biocatalyst system can transform recalcitrant biomass into valuable biofuels, biochemicals, and biomaterials, and demonstrate a model for an unconventional, economical, and competitive integrated biorefinery. The project presented a promising sustainable pathway for energy independence, security, and a greener environment by utilizing renewable, sustainable, and domestic lignocellulosic biomass instead of fossil fuels. To date, this project has generated one book, two book chapters, one provisional patent application, seven published, peer-reviewed papers, one Master thesis, one undergraduate honors thesis, and sixteen oral and poster presentations at both national and international conferences. This project has trained one postdoctoral researcher, 3 graduate students, 10 undergraduate students, and 1 high-schooler from underrepresented minorities in the interdisciplinary research areas of biomass conversion, biocatalysis, systems biology, and metabolic engineering. In addition, the team has engaged undergraduate students to participate not only in various research projects but also in the Internationally Genetically Engineered Machinery competition (iGEM). Notably, the UTK-iGEM team received a Gold medal in 2016 competition for their project on: "Engineering Bacteria to Make Natural Scents from Chemical Wastes." The team has also organized summer workshops for K-12 students who were exposed to various aspects of Catalysis and Biocatalysis to address challenging energy-related problems.
